Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 02:29PM foobs wrote: Finally someone speaking my thoughts.  I hate this, I hate this, I hate this!  How DARE someone try to pick a 'color' for my experience.  I went undetected for years because my stupid Gyn apparently doesn't know about Lobular cancer, Dense breast Tissue and Hormone Replacement Therapy .....................and Doing an ULTRASOUND.  Same exact story for my sister in law.  So where is all the money going?  PINK BROCHURES that assure you 'everything is FINE........  I stopped wearing pink two years ago.  Did I mention that I hate this promotion at our expense?
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 01:45PM foobs wrote: Will any of you brave women who've had BLM with one side prophlactic and who DONT have brca+ tell me if your insurance paid for it?  I'm starting chemo soon, then rads but am definitely planning on a BLM and DIEP reconstruction (have lobular in right breast). I have a sister with breast cancer and lots of other cancers in the family.  I was pre screened for the brca gene but oncologist didn't think I would be positive for it.  So I'm not getting brca tested.  I've NEVER missed a mammogram and noone found this so I don't want to do this again with the other breast!  Thanks for your help!
Posts.Title: preventitive bilateral mastectomy staceyroberts2007 BrandyWK

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2019 01:00PM foobs wrote: 10 YEARS ago I was diagnosed with STAGE III ILC, many positive LN and a significant family history. I never post here anymore but 10 years........ I hope someone just diagnosed will take this honest account to heart, try to be positive through treatment, and be braver than she's ever had to be. I remember getting angry if anyone even suggested my life/health would change after this. I remember thinking "let's just get started so we can finish this! I wanted to win, to throw everything they had at this beast! I was a little naive that way, but all in all, today, I'm pretty healthy, busy, and very happy. Chemo and aromatase inhibitors have taken a toll, but I'm living and it's a good life! My primary care Dr has been wonderful in caring for my long-term issues. His awareness and compassion are rare and I'm lucky to have found him. I don't believe there's enough awareness of the long term effects of breast cancer treatment, even among the oncologist teams. Still, I am so grateful for where their focus is and for them saving lives. I felt vulnerable when chemo, radiation and surgeries were over when I was only checked every 3 and then 6 months. I worked hard to look forward, not back and tried my best not to worry. "Laugh and the world laughs with you, cry and you cry alone"! I asked myself "what's surviving worth if you spend your time worrying"? I now say to myself every morning, "tonight when I go to bed I will say, today was beautiful". Most of us survive this horror. I'm probably older than most of you now, and can tell you that life goes by too fast to let any beast make you afraid for very long.
Posts.Title: Stage III Cancer Survivors .... 10+ Years and Out AlwaysHope karen1956

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2010 10:54AM foobs wrote: I don't even know what to say to you ladies.  jumped on this thread because of the title.  I'm stage III and know how lucky I am I found it myself (thanks to a very stupid gyn).  The rage I feel sometimes for the images portrayed by the little pink general information brochures. pink sh--!  I hate pink!  And the IGNORANCE.  I can only imagine how you feel because its a carefully guarded secret that some of us actually could die.  duh  I want to just punch people who say "you'll be FINE.....my mother was FINE......  And the best one......".you probably won't even lose your hair they way they do things now."  Ok so now they're the experts on all the poison chemo they've been using for over 30 years. Maybe this isn't the place for it but I'm so mad that no one talks about lobular cancer (only 12% of BC diagnosises).  Gyns apparently have no clue that if you have dense breast tissue and take HRT, that mammograms don't do any good.  They don't even suggest an ultrasound--I would have payed for it myself!  Alerted the women in my family and so my sister--dense breast tissue.. had the same experience as I did.....insisted on an ultrasound and lobular cancer was found. I'm so furious.  If I hadn't found mine and then researched for months, my sister & I wouldn't be here.  I barely missed stage IV and realize what a difference III and IV are but I feel your rage and pain.I know how brutal III is and can only imagine the treatments at IV.  WHere is all the money going?  to print pink brochures??!!
Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

Posts.Content: foobs wrote: I'm starting chemo very soon and then possibly radiation, then having a Bilateral Mastx (left side is prophlactic) with immediate DIEP reconstruction.  Rad oncologist tells me he can radiate over DIEP reconstructions, My breast surgeon says no.  Who calls this?  I haven't seen a plastic surgeon yet since its way in the future, after chemo.  But I do not want to do radiation and then find out I can't have a tissue reconstruction.  HELP  I know we have to be flexible but I really need to know I've make the best decisions for what I'm living with at the end of all this.  I hope to get some response.  This is the third time I've posted and no responses.  Am I doing something wrong with my posts? DX: 3/09, ILC, STAGE IIIA, T2 N2, ER+PR+ Her2-, Grade I, 8/12 LN, TX: Chemo, Rads, BMX, Bi lateral DIEP, Aromasin 2009-2014, Tamoxifen-2014-2016 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radiation then DIEP Reconstruction or other way around? foobs foobs

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 09:56AM foobs wrote: No Deanna I'm most definitely having a bilateral even if I get clean margins with the lumpectomy.  Houston was pretty clear about no surgery before chemo if tumor is over 2 cm.  Also having the lymph node biopsy before chemo makes sense to me. This tumor (s?) is very diffuse and odd shaped. I really trust my BS here.  I wish she had a diep PS here so she could do my mastx.  If I could have a bilateral mastx with immediate diep next week in Houston (or here), I would  do that and skip the lumpectomy, but the deip PS (s) are few and far between and you can't get scheduled immediately.  PLUS, I want this thing out of me!  I've heard great things about the BS and diep PS (s) in Houston.  I appreciate having input from all of you.  Its really helping me sort this out.  Rough month, just trying to educate myself!  The stress has really taken a toll and I was so healthy!  (and will be again)  Makes me mad!  None of us planned for this just taking over our lives, right?
Posts.Title: Radiation then DIEP Reconstruction or other way around? foobs foobs

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 08:49AM foobs wrote: Deanna, Lisa Thanks so much for responding!    Oops I forgot to say that I'm having a lumpectomy with lymph node biopsy first (in 2 days here locally) This surgeon knows my hope for bilateral mastx and diep after chemo & radiation. The bilateral mastx is because of strong family history and this sneaky lobular cancer and size of tumor.  Because we don't have a DIEP surgeon here, I have to travel to MD Anderson Houston for the BM and DIEP.  Over the phone, MD Anderson told me that anything over 2 cm has to have chemo first.  So my BS here and I decided to do the lymph node biopsy and lumpectomy (this is looking like it may be two tumors, same quadrant, right breast)   Sounds like I need to get a consult with the BS and PS in Houston and fly down there for a consult after chemo and prior to radiation.  Does this sound reasonable to you?
Posts.Title: Radiation then DIEP Reconstruction or other way around? foobs foobs

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 04:45AM foobs wrote: Unfortunatley, there isn't a diep surgeon in NM at all.  We chose MD Anderson because of insurance benefits, but mostly their reputation is one of the best nationwide. They also have their back up team here in NM and I understand they'll work with me when I get home.  So far the rapport betweeen all the Drs has been seamless--Both oncology and radiation at Presbyterian and MD Anderson here share facilities.  My lumpectomy is tomorrow (Friday).  Yes, I've had an MRI, also a mammogram, Pet scan, bloodwork, biopsy, the works.  I guess its pretty much the same for all of us.  Wish me luck for clear margins and clean lymph nodes tomorrow.  Thanks for your answers to my many questions.
